context: Frédéric François Chopin (/ˈʃoʊpæn/; French pronunciation: ​[fʁe.de.ʁik fʁɑ̃.swa ʃɔ.pɛ̃]; 22 February or 1 March <a5_0><a14_0>1810<a14_0/><a5_0/> – <a10_0>17 October <a18_0>1849<a18_0/><a10_0/>), born <a11_0>Fryderyk Franciszek Chopin<a11_0/>,[n 1] was a <a0_0>Polish and French<a0_0/> (by citizenship and birth of father) composer and a virtuoso pianist of the <a1_0><a6_0><a13_0><a17_0>Romantic<a17_0/> era<a13_0/><a6_0/><a1_0/>, who wrote primarily for the <a2_0><a8_0><a12_0>solo piano<a12_0/><a8_0/><a2_0/>. He gained and has maintained renown worldwide as one of the leading musicians of his era, whose "poetic genius was based on a professional technique that was without equal in his generation." Chopin was born in what was then the <a3_0>Duchy of <a7_0><a15_0>Warsaw<a15_0/><a7_0/><a3_0/>, and grew up in Warsaw, which after 1815 became part of Congress Poland. A child prodigy, he completed his musical education and composed his earlier works in Warsaw before leaving Poland at the age of <a4_0><a9_0><a16_0>20<a16_0/><a9_0/><a4_0/>, less than a month before the outbreak of the November 1830 Uprising.
